1. A 45-year-old man presents with a three-week history of persistent headaches, intermittent low-grade fever, and progressive confusion. He reports recent episodes of blurry vision and transient weakness in his right arm. On examination, he is lethargic with subtle left-sided hemiparesis and mild nuchal rigidity. Laboratory studies reveal elevated inflammatory markers, while cerebrospinal fluid analysis shows lymphocytic pleocytosis with elevated protein. MRI of the brain demonstrates multifocal enhancing lesions in the cerebral cortex and leptomeninges. Cerebral angiography reveals segmental narrowing and beading of intracranial vessels. Brain biopsy confirms granulomatous inflammation involving small- and medium-sized cerebral arteries consistent with granulomatous angiitis. The patient is started on high-dose corticosteroids and cyclophosphamide with gradual clinical improvement.
What brings you in today?
output:

ANSWER: Uh, I’m a 45-year-old man. I’ve had these weird headaches for almost three weeks, and sometimes I feel kind of foggy, like I can’t think straight. I also noticed my vision blurring and some weakness on one side, and I’ve just been feeling really tired and a bit strange.
